head.title: Enhancing the Capacity and Stability of a Tungsten Disulfide Anode in a Lithium-Ion Battery Using Excess Sulfur | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Enhancing the Capacity and Stability of a Tungsten Disulfide Anode in a Lithium-Ion Battery Using Excess Sulfur

Tungsten disulfide (WS2) is a transition metal disulfide and a promising anode material due to its layered structure, making it favorable for attaining lithium-ion batteries with rate capability and thermal/mechanical stability. Although WS2 has a rich redox chemistry and a large density, which can increase the specific capacity and volumetric energy density, it still has an inferior specific capacity and poor long-term stability for practical use due to its insufficient space for the accommodation of lithium ions and large volume change during cycling. Herein, to overcome the chronic limitations of WS2-based anodes, we propose a micron-sized tungsten disulfide/reduced graphene oxide composite by employing excess sulfur (Sx-WS2/r-GO). In particular, the excess sulfur modifies the polarity of r-GO by chemically binding on the r-GO sheet during WS2 formation, leading to an increase in the adsorption strength due to WS2. Moreover, the excess sulfur increases the lattice parameter of WS2 and decreases the crystallinity degree, securing additional sites for the accommodation of lithium ions. Therefore, the excess sulfur can increase the specific capacity and impede the separation of the pulverized WS2 nanoparticles, hence mitigating structural decay during cycling. As a result, the Sx-WS2/r-GO anode exhibits an enhanced specific capacity of 1426 mAh g–1 at 0.4 A g–1 and a high cyclic performance, with 87.9% capacity retention after 4000 cycles at a high current density (2.0 A g–1).

div.p:
Tungsten disulfide (WS
2
) is a transition metal disulfide and a promising anode material due to its layered structure, making it favorable for attaining lithium-ion batteries with rate capability and thermal/mechanical stability. Although WS
2
has a rich redox chemistry and a large density, which can increase the specific capacity and volumetric energy density, it still has an inferior specific capacity and poor long-term stability for practical use due to its insufficient space for the accommodation of lithium ions and large volume change during cycling. Herein, to overcome the chronic limitations of WS
2
-based anodes, we propose a micron-sized tungsten disulfide/reduced graphene oxide composite by employing excess sulfur (S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO). In particular, the excess sulfur modifies the polarity of r-GO by chemically binding on the r-GO sheet during WS
2
formation, leading to an increase in the adsorption strength due to WS
2
. Moreover, the excess sulfur increases the lattice parameter of WS
2
and decreases the crystallinity degree, securing additional sites for the accommodation of lithium ions. Therefore, the excess sulfur can increase the specific capacity and impede the separation of the pulverized WS
2
nanoparticles, hence mitigating structural decay during cycling. As a result, the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO anode exhibits an enhanced specific capacity of 1426 mAh g
–1
at 0.4 A g
–1
and a high cyclic performance, with 87.9% capacity retention after 4000 cycles at a high current density (2.0 A g
–1
).

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are predominant energy storage systems used in portable devices, electrical vehicles, and grid-scale facilities. At present, many advances in technology have required a new active material with a higher gravimetric/volumetric capacity and longer lifetime, exceeding those of presently commercialized materials, such as transition metal oxide cathodes and graphite anodes.
(1,2)
In particular, among the promising candidates for anode materials, lithium (Li) and silicon (Si) have received great attention due to their low operating potential (Li: 0 V
Li/Li+
; Si: 0.4 V
Li/Li+
) and high specific capacity (Li: 3860 mAh g
–1
; Si: 4200 mAh g
–1
). Although many efforts have been made to apply both materials for practical uses, their problematic behaviors, such as large volume expansion and dendrite formation, which lead to poor long-term stability and kinetics, are a major obstacle to practical use.
(3,4)

On the other hand, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) have high electrical conductivity and thermal/mechanical stability, and hence, they are drawing much attention for electrochemical applications.
(5−7)
Moreover, they have been considered attractive anode materials for use in LIBs because of their two-dimensional structure with a covalent bond in the intralayer and weak van der Waals force in the interlayer, which can result in rapid and stable ion transfer within the structure.
(8)
Moreover, most TMDCs have rich redox chemistry and a high specific capacity of 400–900 mAh g
–1
when used in LIB anodes.
(5,9)
Among them, tungsten disulfide (WS
2
) has an advantageous volumetric energy density (3248 mAh cm
–3
) due to its large density (7.5 g cm
–3
), making WS
2
favorable for energy storage systems (ESSs).
(10)
In fact, the intrinsic problem of using WS
2
for LIB applications is its low specific capacity of only 433 mAh g
–1
based on the four-lithium reaction (WS
2
+ 4Li
+
+ 4e
–
→ W + 2Li
2
S) and its high operating voltages of 0.5 and 1.4 V
Li/Li+
when used as an anode.
(11−13)
However, the insufficient capacity and high redox voltage of WS
2
can be improved by designing various structures, such as nanoscale structures and three-dimensional matrixes, because these favorable structures can induce additional redox reactions with the conversion mechanism of WS
2
.
(14−16)
Nevertheless, modified WS
2
materials still have poor structural stability, leading to poor cyclic performance in LIBs due to the loss of active materials by repeated conversion reactions; no more than 500 cycles can have been performed, as described in previous reports.
(17,18)
Hence, many researchers have attempted various strategies to improve stability, which is deeply related to securing stable kinetics: (i) designing nanoscaled materials to reduce the path length for ionic and electronic transport and accommodate mechanical strain and structural distortion
(19,20)
and (ii) blending with conductive carbon, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO), to improve electrical conductivity and buffer structural decay.
(21,22)
Nevertheless, previously reported strategies have not satisfactorily overcome the limitation of long-term stability for practical applications. Hence, we propose a new strategy to simultaneously enhance the stability and kinetics; in this strategy, a WS
2
/r-GO composite is designed by introducing excess sulfur into WS
2
and r-GO to amorphize WS
2
and secure more sites for the accommodation of lithium ions while retaining the layered structure, which simultaneously improves the kinetics and structural stability.

Unlike WS
2
, tungsten trisulfide (WS
3
) has a one-dimensional chain structure that is amorphous and has more open sites for lithium ions, and hence, it has a large storage capacity.
(23,24)
In addition, this amorphous structure has better structural stability than crystalline structures in the case of sulfide-based electrodes because the energy barrier of the structure rearrangement with conversion reactions is low, so amorphous WS
3
tolerates volume change.
(25)
However, its disordered structure mostly shows a poor kinetic performance that is associated with poor ion diffusion.
(26)
Hence, we thought that adding excess sulfur to WS
2
(S
x
-WS
2
) in amounts not exceeding
x
= 1 might yield a material not only with a low crystallinity degree similar to that of WS
3
and a high capacity but also whose kinetics did not deteriorate, because a suitable amount of sulfur can retain the layered structure of WS
2
, which is more favorable to kinetics than the chained structure of WS
3
.
(27)
Therefore, we believed that S
x
-WS
2
(
x
< 1) has a kinetic performance similar to that of WS
2
but better structural stability than WS
2
, approaching that of WS
3
. In addition, to further enhance the structural stability, we used r-GO as a template to retain a robust 2D structure and conductor to improve kinetics.
(28,29)
r-GO maintains the low stacked layered structure of S
x
-WS
2
and its planar geometry, supporting lithium-ion diffusion. In particular, as previously reported, sulfur is one of the heteroatoms that complements the weak interactions between r-GO and sulfides by increasing polarity.
(28,30,31)
Thus, S-doped r-GO can improve structural stability due to the enhanced adsorption capacity of metal sulfides achieved with strong electronic coupling.
(32,33)
Therefore, in addition to binding excess sulfur with WS
2
, we also modified the polarity of r-GO by anchoring r-GO where defects exist. Hence, we designed a one-pot synthesis method to simultaneously introduce excess sulfur into WS
2
and r-GO.

Accordingly, in this work, we prepared a two-dimensional excess sulfur-containing WS
2
/r-GO composite (S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO,
x
< 1), where the excess sulfur in the composite plays two roles: chemically binding to WS
2
and anchoring r-GO, simultaneously. Furthermore, the electrochemical performance of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO is assessed to verify the effect of excess sulfur on the composite for achieving high capacity and long-term stability.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
shows the surface morphologies and chemical characteristics of as-prepared S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and the control group, WS
2
/r-GO. As shown by the morphology and diffraction pattern of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO obtained by SEM (
Figure
1
a) and TEM (
Figure
1
b), respectively, the as-prepared S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO has a micron-sized layered structure, in which WS
2
covers the r-GO sheets, and a ring pattern indicating a low crystallinity degree is shown by the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern. Also, the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (
Table S1
) indicates that the atomic ratio of S to W is 2.41, which means that the atomic amount of excess sulfur (
x
) is 0.41 in the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO composite. However, in the S
x
-WS
2
material without r-GO sheets, stacked and curled layers are observed (
Figure S1
), meaning that r-GO prevents the stacking of WS
2
and supports the growth of a layered structure along the surface of r-GO. As shown in
Figure
1
c,d, in the case of the as-prepared WS
2
/r-GO composite without excess sulfur, a two-dimensional polycrystalline structure was observed, with (002), (100), (110), and (200) planes. The interplanar spacing between the (002) planes was confirmed to be 0.616 nm, meaning that the material is based on crystalline WS
2
.
(34)
From the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared powder samples (
Figure
1
e), it is confirmed that the GO peak at 11.4° disappears, and broad peaks associated with r-GO appear at 28.6° and 42.3° for the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO composites.
(35)
This indicates that GO is reduced by chemically anchoring WS
2
. Furthermore, in WS
2
/r-GO, peaks attributed to WS
2
clearly appear at 14.6°, 29.5°, and 50.4°, while, in S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, the peaks become less intense and broaden.
(36)
The XRD pattern is consistent with the results of the SAED patterns; that is, excess sulfur decreases the crystallinity degree of WS
2
.
Figure
1
f and
Figure S2
show the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results of the as-prepared materials.
(55)
According to the carbon (C 1s) and oxygen (O 1s) XPS spectra, S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO shows relatively high-intensity peaks for carbon–oxygen bonds with a high oxygen ratio (C═O: 287.7 and 532.2 eV; O–C–O: 288.9 eV; and C–OOH: 289.7 eV), but a smaller peak is observed for quinone (531.0 eV) in the O 1s XPS spectrum, indicating that the excess sulfur decreases the degree of the reduction of GO.
(37)
Moreover, the peak corresponding to the C–S bond (286.7 eV) in the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO spectrum is larger than the peaks corresponding to other oxidized carbons, indicating that the excess sulfur would be embedded into sites of r-GO, such as defects, during the reduction of the oxygen functional group of GO, which can be favorable to the stability of r-GO-based composite materials.
(38)
The Raman spectra of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, WS
2
/r-GO, and GO exhibit D bands (∼1350 cm
–1
) and G bands (∼1585 cm
–1
), which are associated with the degree of graphitization (
Figure
1
g). In particular, S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO exhibit a downshift in frequency for the G band; the G bands for S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, WS
2
/r-GO, and GO are located at 1581, 1579, and 1598 cm
–1
, respectively. It is well-known that the reduction of GO induces a downshift in the G band by decreasing the number of sp
3
carbons with large oxidation levels.
(39,40)
In addition, the excess sulfur anchored on r-GO can cause an electron doping effect similar to heteroatom doping,
(41)
and hence, S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO might have a slightly large frequency G band than WS
2
/r-GO. Furthermore, the intensity ratios of the D to G bands (
I
D
/
I
G
), which are associated with the defect density of graphene, show an increasing tendency in S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO, though the
I
D
/
I
G
of the former is larger; the
I
D
/
I
G
ratios of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, WS
2
/r-GO, and GO are 1.15, 1.08, and 0.99, respectively. This indicates that the restoration of graphitic carbon by the reduction of GO induces an increase in the number of defects, and the excess sulfur anchored on the defects of r-GO causes the structural distortion of carbon by mechanisms such as amorphization.
(42)
On the basis of XRD and XPS analyses, it is confirmed that the composite with WS
2
induces the reduction of GO, and the excess sulfur chemically bound on r-GO causes structural enlargement, reducing the crystallinity degree and further increasing
I
D
/
I
G
, which might improve the kinetics and capacity for the accommodation of lithium ions.

div.p:
Figure 1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns, X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra, and laser Raman spectroscopy spectra of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO. (a) SEM image and (b) HR-TEM bright field image of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO (inset: selected area electron diffraction patterns). (c) SEM image and (d) HR-TEM bright field image of WS
2
/r-GO GO (inset: selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns). (e) XRD patterns of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, WS
2
/r-GO, and GO. (f) C 1s and O 1s XPS spectra of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO surfaces. (g) Raman spectra of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, WS
2
/r-GO, and GO.

div.div:
The electrochemical cycling test of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO half-cells between 0.005 and 3.0 V at 0.4 A g
–1
is shown along with a comparison with the control group of WS
2
/r-GO in
Figure
2
a. S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO results in a rapidly declining capacity from 1232 to 415 mAh g
–1
for the initial 20 cycles (
step 1
). This rapid capacity fading occurs because of the irreversible reaction of lithium ions, forming an SEI layer.
(43,44)
Over the subsequent 400 cycles, the capacity gradually increases and up to 1426 mAh g
–1
, which is 116% of the initial capacity (
step 2
). However, although the WS
2
/r-GO half-cell has a higher initial discharge capacity of 1424 mAh g
–1
than S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO, it does not recover to its initial level after rapid capacity fading to 432 mAh g
–1
for 20 cycles. After 400 cycles, the capacity of WS
2
/r-GO remains at only 30% of its initial capacity and does not further decline. To elucidate the difference in the initial cycling behaviors related to the formation cycling of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells, the morphologies of both electrodes were observed using TEM for the uncycled state and 400th cycle. Both uncycled electrodes present the same micron-sized layered structure (
Figure
2
b,d). After 400 cycles, however, WS
2
/r-GO shows small nanoparticles with sizes of 2–4 nm along the r-GO surface (
Figure
2
c). However, aggregated particles with metallic tungsten (W) and a lattice parameter of approximately 0.211 nm are observed in part of WS
2
/r-GO (
Figures
2
c and
S3a
).
(45)
Moreover, some W nanoparticles are detached from the r-GO sheets (
Figure S3b
). In contrast, S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO shows relatively large nanoparticles with sizes in the tens of nanometers range at the 200th cycle of capacity growth (
Figure S4a
). After repetitive conversion reactions (400 cycles), S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO presents uniformly dispersed nanoparticles with sizes of 4–8 nm along the r-GO surface (
Figure
2
e). In addition, lattices with spacings of 0.201 nm, attributed to metallic W, and 0.279 nm, attributed to (100) WS
2
, are observed.
(45,46)
The recombination of WS
2
by delithiation seems to be more activated in the presence of excess sulfur due to the densely adsorbed products on r-GO during lithiation.
(47)
Thus, it is supposed that recombination increases the size of the particles more than in the case of the WS
2
/r-GO electrode. The SAED patterns of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO cycled 400 times display that the polycrystalline structure becomes amorphized (inset image in
Figure
2
d,e). WS
2
gradually decomposes into nanoparticles with phase transformation to metallic W through repeated conversion reactions, resulting in a decline in the crystallinity degree. Consequently, since excess sulfur anchored on r-GO improves the polarity of r-GO, the sulfur more strongly adsorbs electrochemically reacted WS
2
than bare r-GO. Therefore, the electrode containing excess sulfur has a large adsorption capacity, so sulfur can suppress agglomeration and detachment that cause structural collapse due to repetitive conversion reactions. Since the uniformly dispersed nanoparticles along the r-GO surface have a large surface area, the number of active sites increases, resulting in an improvement of the capacity. Additionally, the amorphous structure formed by performing repeated conversion reactions for 400 cycles increases the capacity because it provides more active sites for the accommodation of lithium ions than the crystalline structure provides in common WS
2
.
(16,25)

div.p:
Figure 2. Electrochemical cyclability tests and HR-TEM images of the WS
2
/r-GO and S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrodes evaluated during 800 cycles. (a) The electrochemical cyclability tests were carried out for WS
2
/r-GO and S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO by cycling between 0.005 and 3.0 V at 0.4 A g
–1
for 800 cycles. (b, c) HR-TEM bright field images of the WS
2
/r-GO electrode in the uncycled state and after 400 cycles (inset: SAED patterns and scheme for pristine and 400th cycles). (d, e) HR-TEM bright field images of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrode taken before and after 400 cycles (inset: SAED patterns and scheme for pristine and 400th cycles).

div.div:
Figure
3
a shows the Nyquist plots of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells in the uncycled state and after 1, 100, and 400 cycles. The high-frequency region (HFR) and middle-frequency region (MFR) are related to the three resistances of the solution, solid electrolyte interphase, and charge transfer (
R
s
,
R
SEI
, and
R
ct
).
(48,49)
Table S2
shows the fitting results obtained from the expected equivalent circuit for the half-cells in the HFR and MFR. The charge transfer resistance of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO increases from 74.4 to 150.3 ohm-cm
2
, even up to 100 cycles, and it still has a relatively high resistance compared to that of WS
2
/r-GO (82.8 ohm-cm
2
for 100 cycles). However, after 400 cycles, the charge transfer resistance of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO gradually decreases to 24.7 ohm-cm
2
and shows a lower resistance than WS
2
/r-GO (32.9 ohm-cm
2
). Moreover, the diffusivity of lithium ions in the electrode, corresponding to the Warburg impedance, is calculated using
eq S1
in the Supporting Information.
(50)
The diffusivity of lithium ions in S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO decreases to 1.94 × 10
–7
cm
2
s
–1
after 1 cycle but steadily increases to 4.38 × 10
–7
cm
2
s
–1
as cycling progresses, resulting in a higher value than that obtained for the uncycled electrode (
Figure
3
b). WS
2
/r-GO presents a similar tendency, but the electrode cycled 400 times has a lower diffusivity of 3.45 × 10
–7
cm
2
s
–1
than S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analyses are consistent with the TEM results. Although the initial charge transfer resistance and diffusivity of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO are inferior due to its low crystallinity degree and high content of insulating S, those of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO cycled 400 times are significantly improved due to the uniformly dispersed nanoparticles and lack of structural decay.
Figure
3
c,d shows the charge/discharge profile and differential capacity (d
Q
/d
V
) measured in the potential range between 0.005 and 3.0 V for the 1st and 401st cycles. For the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrode during the initial cycle, two lithiation peaks are observed at 1.69 and 0.67 V, corresponding to the reduction of WS
2
to metallic W and Li
2
S by intercalation and conversion reactions, respectively.
(51)
In addition, below 0.5 V, a broad peak is observed and attributed to SEI layer formation on the surface and the intercalation of lithium ions into r-GO.
(35)
For the initial delithiation process, three oxidation peaks appear at 1.17, 1.89, and 2.31 V, corresponding to the oxidation of W to W
4+
and W
6+
and conversion of Li
2
S to S, respectively.
(47,52)
In the 1st cycle of the WS
2
/r-GO half-cell, d
Q
/d
V
also exhibits a similar curve, indicating that excess sulfur has little effect on the initial reaction of WS
2
. However, in the 401st cycle, the distinct peaks disappear and become rough because of a decrease in the crystallinity degree. Furthermore, because the uniformly dispersed nanoparticles formed due to strong adsorption induced by excess sulfur improve the capacity of lithium ions, the curve of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO has a larger area than that of WS
2
/r-GO. Moreover, since r-GO embedded with S increases the number of sites available for lithium-ion accommodation, a large amount of lithium ions can still react at 0.5 V in the 401st cycle.
(53,54)
After 400 cycles, both half-cells of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO hold at that level for the next 430 cycles (
Figure
2
a,
step 3
). S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO no longer shows the capacity recovery shown in
step 2
. In the HR-TEM bright field image of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrode after 600 cycles (
Figure S5
), the particles with sizes of 5–8 nm and lattice parameters of approximately 0.194 and 0.290 nm are uniformly dispersed along the r-GO sheet without further pulverization, and the structure remains amorphous. The recovery phenomenon of the capacity is caused by the increase in surface area as the microscale structure is pulverized into a nanoscale structure, and the number of storage sites for lithium ions increases as the crystallinity degree decreases. Therefore, it is assumed that there is no capacity increase in
step 3
, and no more change occurs in the morphology and crystallinity of the particles.

Q
/d
V
) of S
x

2
/r-GO and WS

x
-WS
2
/r-GO (red lines) and WS
2
/r-GO (blue lines) half-cells taken before and after 1, 100, and 400 cycles. All EIS curves are fit to be less than 5.0% (gray lines). (b) The diffusivity of lithium ions in the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells is calculated from the Warburg constant in the EIS curve taken before and after 1, 100, and 400 cycles. (c) The charge/discharge profile of S
x

/r-GO and WS

after 1 cycle and 401 cycles. (d) Differential capacity derived from the charge/discharge profile of the S

div.div:
Figure S6
exhibits the electrochemical performance of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells at varying current densities between 0.2 and 2.0 A g
–1
. The S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO half-cell deliveries the capacity of 1728.9, 1472.0, 1083.1, and 781.4 mAh g
–1
at 0.2, 0.4, 1.0, and 2.0 A g
–1
, respectively, whereas WS
2
/r-GO shows the low capacity of 557.2, 491.6, 378.0, and 273.3 mAh g
–1
. It implies that the uniformly dispersed nanoparticles in S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO can provide many active sites to react even at high current density.
Figure
4
a shows the high-rate cyclability of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells cycled 400 times at a current density of 2.0 A g
–1
. The initial capacities of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells are 466.9 and 519.9 mAh g
–1
, respectively. The initial capacity of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO is 2.6 times lower than that of the low-rate test performed at 0.4 A g
–1
presumably because of the decrease in the electrical conductivity caused by the excess sulfur. During 4000 cycles, however, WS
2
/r-GO shows a low capacity retention of 49.6%, whereas S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO maintains a capacity retention of 87.9% (410.4 mAh g
–1
at 2.0 A g
–1
). This is because the excess sulfur can secure the pulverized nanoparticles on the r-GO framework, even though the repetitive conversion reaction induces the pulverization and separation of the activated WS
2
particles.
Figure
4
b–e shows SEM images of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO electrodes in the uncycled states and after cycling 800 times. The uncycled S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrode presents a uniform micron-sized layered structure on its surface (
Figure
4
b). The electrode cycled 800 times shows aggregation due to repetitive conversion reactions, but prominent structural decay was not shown. Moreover, the high-magnification SEM image shows the granular structure of particles with sizes of approximately 120.2 nm and the numerous pores on the layered r-GO template (
Figure
4
c). In contrast, WS
2
/r-GO no longer has distinguishable particles on the r-GO sheet after 800 cycles (
Figure
4
e), although the uncycled electrode has a morphology similar to that of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO (
Figure
4
d). During the long-term cycling test, the structure of WS
2
/r-GO collapses, whereas S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO has a larger surface area than the uncycled half-cell due to the presence of small particles with numerous pores. This result demonstrates that excess sulfur improves structural stability and mitigates the aggregation of particles, even at a high-rate test.

div.p:
Figure 4. Long-term electrochemical performance of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO cycled 4000 times at a high current density. SEM images of the S
x

/r-GO electrodes in the uncycled state and after cycling 800 times. (a) The long-term cyclability and Coulombic efficiency (CE) performance of S

for 4000 cycles after 400 cycles. SEM images of the S

2
/r-GO electrode (d) in the uncycled state and (e) after 800 cycles.

div.div:
On the basis of the above results, chemically anchoring excess sulfur on WS
2
and r-GO can improve both their stability and capacity through modifying the adsorption property and crystallinity of the composite, respectively. As shown in
Figure
5
, after repetitive conversion reactions, the composite retains uniformed particles on the r-GO sheet without agglomeration and detachment due to the improved interaction between WS
2
and r-GO caused by the chemically anchored S. Consequently, structural stability and the surface area can be greatly improved simultaneously by the incorporation of excess sulfur through the formation of uniform and sturdy nanoparticles during formation cycling. This leads to an enhancement in the electrochemical performances, a high capacity exceeding the theoretical capacity, a low internal resistance, a high diffusivity of lithium ions, and a high-rate long-term stability. Furthermore, through a comparative study on the electrochemical performances of recent previously reported WS
2
-based anode materials (
Table S3
and
Figure S7
), our WS
2
with excess sulfur (S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO) could be considered the best candidate, showing the high capacity, high-rate performance, and long-term stability.
(56−61)

div.p:
Figure 5. Schematic showing S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO. To prevent the detachment and aggregation of nanoparticles by repetitive conversion reactions, the WS
2
/r-GO composite was supplemented with excess sulfur. The excess sulfur was chemically bound on the r-GO sheet as well as the WS
2
layer, resulting in particles being uniformly dispersed along the r-GO sheet without inducing structural collapse.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we successfully synthesized an S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO composite with excess sulfur and a micron-scaled layered structure by a one-pot preparation method. The excess sulfur played two roles: simultaneously chemically binding to WS
2
, leading to a low crystallinity degree, while securely anchoring to r-GO, complementing the weak interaction between r-GO and sulfides by increasing the polarity. Hence, the enhanced adsorption strength of WS
2
on r-GO by the excess sulfur effectively mitigated the agglomeration and detachment of the pulverized WS
2
nanoparticles that formed by repetitive conversion reactions. In particular, the uniformly dispersed nanoparticles with a low crystallinity degree provided many active sites and high structural stability, contributing to the capacity increase and long-term stability. As a result, the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO half-cell after 400 cycles exhibited a high specific capacity (1426 mAh g
–1
at a current density of 0.4 A g
–1
) and excellent long-term stability (capacity retention of 87.9% after 4000 cycles at 2.0 A g
–1
). This work will provide an efficient way to overcome the chronic limitations of metal sulfides for their practical applications in lithium-ion batteries.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
Synthesis of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO Composite
div.div:
Graphene oxide (GO) was produced using a modified Hummers method. Graphite (Aldrich) was dispersed in sulfuric acid (H
2
SO
4
, 98 wt %, Daejung), and potassium permanganate (KMnO
4
, Aldrich) was slowly added to the solution. The temperature of the mixture was maintained at 60 °C for 6 h and cooled down to room temperature. Then, deionized water and hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
, 30 wt %, Daejung) were put into the mixture to remove the residual product. The product was separated by centrifugation, followed by freeze-drying at −45 °C for 24 h. Ammonium tetrathiotungstate ((NH
4
)
2
WS
4
, Aldrich) was dispersed in deionized water with sonication and mixed with as-prepared GO by stirring at room temperature. Hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt %, Aldrich) was slowly poured into the mixture. The amount of acid is determined by the stoichiometric ratio; WS
4
2–
+ (4 –
x
)HCl → S
x
-WS
2
+ (2 –
x
/2)H
2
S + (4 –
x
)Cl
–
,
x
< 1. After the diffusion of hydrogen sulfide (H
2
S) gas was completed, the product was separated by centrifugation and then washed with deionized water and acetone several times to remove the residual reactant. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C for 30 min.

The morphologies of the synthesized S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO composites were studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-4700, Hitachi) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, FEI). The crystal structures of the materials were detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/MAX 2500, Rigaku). The chemical bonds of the synthesized materials were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, NEXSA, Thermo Fisher). The characteristic peaks of the carbon materials were evaluated by laser Raman spectroscopy (NRS-5100, JASCO). To acquire the active materials of the electrodes, the cells were disassembled in an Ar-filled glovebox and washed in dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to remove oxidized salts. The changes in the morphology of the active materials of the electrodes induced by cycling were observed by HR-TEM.

The slurry used for the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO (
x
< 1) and WS
2
/r-GO anodes was made of 80 wt % active material, 10 wt % activated carbon (Super C, TIMCAL), and 10 wt % polyvinylidene fluoride (PVdF, Aldrich) binder in an
N
-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution. The prepared slurries were coated onto copper foil and dried at 80 °C for 12 h under vacuum. The prepared S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO electrode has an areal density of 0.3 mg cm
–2
and volumetric density of 152.8 mg cm
–3
. The electrochemical analyses of the S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO half-cells were performed using 2032 coin cells. The half-cells were fabricated using S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO and WS
2
/r-GO as cathodes, lithium metal foil as the counter/reference electrode, 60 μL of 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF
6
) in ethylene carbonate:diethyl carbonate (EC:DEC, 1:1 v/v%) as the electrolyte, and a polymer separator (Celgard 2400) in a glovebox filled with Ar. To measure the electrochemical performances of the half-cell, galvanostatic charge/discharge tests and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were carried out. The cycling performance and charge/discharge profile were obtained using a battery cycler system (WBCS 3000S, WonATech) operated between 0.005 and 3.0 V
Li/Li+
at 0.4 and 2.0 A g
–1
and room temperature. The specific capacity is calculated based on the weight of S
x
-WS
2
/r-GO (80 wt %) in the entire electrode. EIS was performed over a frequency range from 1.0 MHz to 1 mHz at a 5.0 mV amplitude using a potentiostat (HCP-803, BioLogic).

The authors declare that the data supporting the findings of this study are available within the article and its
Supporting Information
file. All other relevant data supporting the findings of this study are available on request.

This review covers key technol. developments and scientific challenges for a broad range of Li-ion battery electrodes. Periodic table and potential/capacity plots are used to compare many families of suitable materials. Performance characteristics, current limitations, and recent breakthroughs in the development of com. intercalation materials such as lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM), lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), lithium titanium oxide (LTO) and others are contrasted with that of conversion materials, such as alloying anodes (Si, Ge, Sn, etc.), chalcogenides (S, Se, Te), and metal halides (F, Cl, Br, I). New polyanion cathode materials are also discussed. The cost, abundance, safety, Li and electron transport, volumetric expansion, material dissoln., and surface reactions for each type of electrode materials are described. Both general and specific strategies to overcome the current challenges are covered and categorized.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

Si has been regarded as one of the most promising next generation lithium-ion battery (LIB) anodes due to its exceptional capacity and proper working voltage. However, the dramatic vol. change during lithiation/delithiation processes has caused severe detrimental consequences, leading to very poor cyclic stability. It has been one of the crit. problems hampering the practical applications of the silicon based LIB anode. Extensive research has been carried out to resolve the problem since early 1990s. For the first time, the studies on the Si anode in the time frame more than two decades are summarized and discussed in this review with a novel chronicle perspective. Through this article, the evolution of the concept, fundamental scientific and technol. development of the silicon LIB anode are clearly presented. It provides unique eyesight into this rapid developing field and will shed light on the future trend of the Si LIB anode research.

An ultrafast and simple strategy to synthesize metal sulfides (MoS2 and WS2) anchored on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) composites is reported as anode materials for Li ion batteries (LIBs). Metal sulfide nanocrystals with homogeneous dispersion onto conducting RGO sheets are obtained in only 45 s by hybrid microwave annealing (HMA) method. The synthesized materials, esp. MoS2/RGO composite, exhibit a high Li capacity, an excellent rate capability, and a stable cycling performance, comparable to the reported best MS2/C composite electrodes. The results highlight the effectiveness of HMA method to fabricate the metal sulfide/RGO composites with excellent elec. properties.

A review. Tungsten is the heaviest transition metal in the family of common transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs). Despite the essential similarities of TMDCs, the considerable differences in the size and charge of the building elements can make the typical 2D layered structure suitable for various applications. There is not much flexibility on the chalcogen side, as the popular elements are S and Se. Following the successful history of transition metal sulfides in various applications, transition metal selenides are now the rising stars. On the transition metal side, WS2 and WSe2 have recently attracted considerable attention. In comparison with the Mo counterparts, W is more abundant in the Earth's crust and thus cheaper, and less toxic. The significantly larger size of W atoms can substantially tune the TMDC properties. The popularity of molybdenum dichalcogenides has somehow overshadowed the potentials of tungsten dichalcogenides. This manuscript attempts to collect the recent reports on various applications of WS2 and WSe2 to provide a general overview of tungsten dichalcogenides. Due to the popularity of sulfides, the prime focus of the present review is on WSe2, which is an emerging member of this family. Although WTe2 is not a common material like all transition metal tellurides, it is also briefly reviewed as a member of this sub-family of TMDCs owing to its unique properties, which named it as a potential candidate for giant magnetoresistance and supercond.

A review. Advanced electrodes with a high energy d. at high power are urgently needed for high-performance energy storage devices, including lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and supercapacitors (SCs), to fulfill the requirements of future electrochem. power sources for applications such as in hybrid elec./plug-in-hybrid (HEV/PHEV) vehicles. Metal sulfides with unique phys. and chem. properties, as well as high specific capacity/capacitance, which are typically multiple times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials, are currently studied as promising electrode materials. However, the implementation of these sulfide electrodes in practical applications is hindered by their inferior rate performance and cycling stability. Nanostructures offering the advantages of high surface-to-vol. ratios, favorable transport properties, and high freedom for the vol. change upon ion insertion/extn. and other reactions, present an opportunity to build next-generation LIBs and SCs. Thus, the development of novel concepts in material research to achieve new nanostructures paves the way for improved electrochem. performance. Herein, we summarize recent advances in nanostructured metal sulfides, such as iron sulfides, copper sulfides, cobalt sulfides, nickel sulfides, manganese sulfides, molybdenum sulfides, tin sulfides, with zero-, one-, two-, and three-dimensional morphologies for LIB and SC applications. In addn., the recently emerged concept of incorporating conductive matrixes, esp. graphene, with metal sulfide nanomaterials will also be highlighted. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and perspectives for the future development of metal sulfide-based LIB and SC devices.

Thin films of tungsten sulfide (WS2) are prepd. by at. layer deposition (ALD) and its intercalation properties as an anode material in Li-ion battery are studied. The self-satn. growth of the material and the temp. window for ALD growth is confirmed by in situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM). In situ Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR) and residual gas analyzer (RGA) studies help to predict the two half reactions and FTIR further validates the self-limiting feature of ALD growth. The as-grown WS2 is amorphous in nature and characterized in detail by XPS and Raman spectroscopic anal. The as-grown films are tested as a suitable intercalation based material for Li-ion battery anode. CV measurements are carried out extensively to explore the dominant intercalation property of the WS2 anode. Stable cycling performance with high coulombic efficiency (>99%) up to 100 charge-discharge cycles is obsd. To enhance the performance further, multi walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) scaffold layer is introduced that helps to deposit more active material for the same no. of ALD cycles.

Although tungsten disulfide (WS2), an analog of graphite, has long been pursued as a promising energy storage material due to its unique layered structure, structural changes, volumetric expansion and poor electronic cond. have limited its practical use. Here, we report the synthesis of porous WS2 composed of a few layered nanosheets (P-WS2) using a simple and scalable hydrothermal method, as well as its electrochem. properties when used for a lithium storage electrode, a supercapacitor electrode, and a visible light active photocatalytic material. P-WS2 as an anode for lithium-ion batteries showed a high specific capacity of 292 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 0.2C with excellent cycling stability over 100 cycles. The half-cell electrochem. assembly test demonstrated that P-WS2 delivered 241.5 F/g at a c.d. of 0.75 A/g and showed excellent stability over 2000 consecutive charge-discharge cycles. P-WS2 nanosheets exhibited 10 times higher photocatalytic activity than bulk com. WS2 (C-WS2) for the degrdn. of Rhodamine B dye under visible light irradn. The excellent performance of P-WS2 is due to its sheet-like structure, porous characteristics, and high surface area.

A review. Nanostructured materials offer the possibility to make use of small transport lengths and small sepn. distances similar to fluids, but unlike fluids, the higher structural stability of the solid state can be taken advantage of. Recent results on Li-batteries highlight the potential for room temp. applications. Advantages and disadvantages of nanostructured matter are discussed with respect to stability, storage capacity, voltage and charging/discharging rates. A novel interfacial storage mechanism for Li which, in the mesoscopic case, forms a bridge between batteries and capacitors, is presented.

Lithium ion battery applications of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) nanocomposites
Stephenson, Tyler; Li, Zhi; Olsen, Brian; Mitlin, David

A review. This is the first targeted review of the synthesis - microstructure - electrochem. performance relations of MoS2 - based anodes and cathodes for secondary lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Molybdenum disulfide is a highly promising material for LIBs that compensates for its intermediate insertion voltage (∼2 V vs. Li/Li+) with a high reversible capacity (up to 1290 mA h g-1) and an excellent rate capability (e.g. 554 mA h g-1 after 20 cycles at 50 C). Several themes emerge when surveying the scientific literature on the subject: first, we argue that there is excellent data to show that truly nanoscale structures, which often contain a nanodispersed carbon phase, consistently possess superior charge storage capacity and cycling performance. We provide several hypotheses regarding why the measured capacities in such architectures are well above the theor. predictions of the known MoS2 intercalation and conversion reactions. Second, we highlight the growing microstructural and electrochem. evidence that the layered MoS2 structure does not survive past the initial lithiation cycle, and that subsequently the electrochem. active material is actually elemental sulfur. Third, we show that certain synthesis techniques are consistently demonstrated to be the most promising for battery applications, and describe these in detail. Fourth, we present our selection of synthesis methods that we believe to have a high potential for creating improved MoS2 LIB electrodes, but are yet to be tried.

Transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), a two-dimensional (2D) nanostructured material, has, to a greater extent, technol. applications in catalysis, sensors, lithium-ion batteries, and optoelectronic devices due to their unique structure and elec. properties. Recently, the 2D TMD tungsten disulfide (WS2) has been regarded as one of the most promising anode candidates for lithium-ion batteries. However, the exploration of the WS2 sheets with the 1T metallic phase still remains a prodigious challenge to improve its cond. and cycling stability in the application of lithium-ion batteries. In this work, the highly rich 1T few-layered WS2 nanoflowers (referred to as rich 1T WS2 NFs) were synthesized, exhibiting a rich 1T metallic phase with few-layered structures around the active edge sites of the NFs for achieving a fast electron/ion transfer, thereby delivering the enhanced cycling performance and lithium storage. The rich 1T WS2 NFs exhibits an irreversible capacity (charge capacity) of 810 mA h g-1 at 0.2 C, and after five cycles the av. reversible capacity (discharge capacity) exhibits 609, 577, 554, 542, 530, and 504 mA h g-1, with the increased c-rates of 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1, 1.5, and 2.0 C, resp. In addn., the rich 1T WS2 NFs anode without addnl. carbon support exhibits an initial capacity of 890 mA h g-1 and still remains at a capacity of 390 mA h g-1 after 500 cycles, being better than the 2H WS2 NFs and the bulk WS2 sheets. This excellent rate of performance is further attributed to the rich 1T metallic nature of the few-layered WS2 NFs that could well-promote the excellent cycling stability and rate capability in contrast to the carbon free (i.e., graphene, CNTs) composites. More importantly, the enlarged interlayer spacing (i.e., 0.67 nm) and its rich 1T metallic nature are beneficial for the high capacity and improved long cycling stability and thus makes a potential candidate for the superior Li-ion storage anodes.

The authors demonstrate the feasibility of tungsten disulfide nanotubes (WS2-NTs)/graphene (GS) sandwich-type architecture as anode for lithium-ion batteries. The graphene-based hierarchical architecture plays vital roles in achieving fast electron/ion transfer, thus leading to good electrochem. performance. When evaluated as anode, the WS2-NTs/GS hybrid could maintain a capacity of 318.6 mA/g over 500 cycles at a c.d. of 1A/g. Besides, the hybrid anode does not require any addnl. polymetric binder, conductive additives, or a sep. metal current-collector. The relatively high d. of this hybrid is beneficial for high capacity per unit vol. Those characteristics make it a potential anode material for light and high-performance lithium-ion batteries.

MoO3 coatings are synthesized on anodic TiO2 nanotube arrays by electrodeposition, as a self-standing, binder-free anode material in Li-ion batteries for enhancing the Li-ion insertion performance. Our results show that both the coated TiO2 nanotubes deliver much higher areal capacities than bare nanotubes or a dense cryst. α-MoO3 film, while the cryst. α-MoO3 coating greatly increases the areal capacity of TiO2 nanotubes compared to the amorphous. The results are obtained at 1340 μA h cm-2 initial capacity for nanotubes with a cryst. coating, 977 μA h cm-2 for those with an amorphous coating and 342 μA h cm-2 for the bare ones. The significant enhancement is due to a combination of MoO3 with high specific capacity and TiO2 nanotube arrays with large surface area allowing uniform MoO3 deposition and rapid ionic transfer. Cryst. α-MoO3 is better than amorphous MoO3 and the coating medium is discussed in terms of chem. state, crystal defects, capacitive contributions and the charge-discharge kinetics in coated TiO2 nanotube electrodes.

Heterogeneous electrode materials with hierarchical architectures promise to enable considerable improvement in future energy storage devices. In this study, we report on a tailored synthetic strategy used to create heterogeneous tungsten sulfide/oxide core-shell nanofiber materials with vertically and randomly aligned thorn-bush features, and we evaluate them as potential anode materials for high-performance Na-ion batteries. The WSx (2 ≤ x ≤ 3, amorphous WS3 and cryst. WS2) nanofiber is successfully prepd. by electrospinning and subsequent calcination in a reducing atm. To prevent capacity degrdn. of the WSx anodes originating from sulfur dissoln., a facile post-thermal treatment in air is applied to form an oxide passivation surface. Interestingly, WO3 thorn bundles are randomly grown on the nanofiber stem, resulting from the surface conversion. We elucidate the evolving morphol. and structural features of the nanofibers during post-thermal treatment. The heterogeneous thorn-bush nanofiber electrodes deliver a high second discharge capacity of 791 mAh g-1 and improved cycle performance for 100 cycles compared to the pristine WSx nanofiber. We show that this hierarchical design is effective in reducing sulfur dissoln., as shown by cycling anal. with counter Na electrodes.

Na ion batteries (SIBs) have been considered a promising alternative to Li ion batteries for large-scale energy storage. However, their inferior electrochem. performances, esp. cyclability, become the major challenge for further development of SIBs. Large vol. change and sluggish diffusion kinetics are generally considered to be responsible for the fast capacity degrdn. We report the strong chem. bonding of nanostructured Sb2S3 on S-doped graphene sheets (Sb2S3/SGS) that enables a stable capacity retention of 83% for 900 cycles with high capacities and excellent rate performances. To the best of our knowledge, the cycling performance of the Sb2S3/SGS composite is superior to those reported for any other Sb-based materials for SIBs. Computational calcns. demonstrate that S-doped graphene (SGS) has a stronger affinity for Sb2S3 and the discharge products than pure graphene, resulting in a robust composite architecture for outstanding cycling stability. Our study shows a feasible and effective way to solve the long-term cycling stability issue for SIBs.

The aim of the contribution is to introduce a high performance anode alternative to graphite for lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). A simple process was employed to synthesize uniform graphene-like few-layer tungsten sulfide (WS2) supported on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) through a hydrothermal synthesis route. The WS2-RGO (80:20 and 70:30) composites exhibited good enhanced electrochem. performance and excellent rate capability performance when used as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. The specific capacity of the WS2-RGO composite delivered a capacity of 400-450 mAh g-1 after 50 cycles when cycled at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1. At 4000 mA g-1, the composites showed a stable capacity of approx. 180-240 mAh g-1, resp. The noteworthy electrochem. performance of the composite is not additive, rather it is synergistic in the sense that the electrochem. performance is much superior compared to both WS2 and RGO. As the obsd. lithiation/delithiation for WS2-RGO is at a voltage≈1.0 V (≈0.1 V for graphite, Li+/Li), the lithium-ion battery with WS2-RGO is expected to possess high interface stability, safety and management of elec. energy is expected to be more efficient and economic.

A high S-doping amt. reduces the irreversible lithium storage sites on graphene, and the first coulombic efficiency is as high as 81.7%. In addn., thin-layered and small-sized SnS can alleviate the structural damage caused by vol. expansion and shrinkage; therefore, a high specific capacity of 893.9 mA h g-1 is retained after 100 cycles.

A high-pressure assisted hydrothermal treatment is proposed as a facile, green and efficient route for the redn. of aq. dispersions of graphene oxide. Reactions were performed in an autoclave at mild temp. (180 °C) using only water and nitrogen or hydrogen gas. No further sepn. or purifn. of the reduced products was required. XPS, Fourier transform IR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric anal. revealed that the application of high pressure significantly enhanced oxygen removal. The C/O at. ratio of the graphene oxide sheets increased from 1.65 to 5.29 upon conventional hydrothermal treatment using autogenous pressure. Higher C/O ratios of 6.35 and 7.93 were obtained for graphene oxides that were reduced under high-pressure of nitrogen and hydrogen, resp. Specifically, the use of high-pressure hydrogen improved the removal of oxygen double-bonded to carbon. The introduction of covalently bonded heteroatoms, which is commonly obsd. for the use of reductants such as hydrazine, was not detected. Furthermore, high-pressure redn. led to a better restoration of the sp2 conjugation than was obtained by conventional hydrothermal treatment, as detd. by XPS and Raman spectroscopies. These findings illustrate the promise of high-pressure hydrothermal treatments for the eco-friendly mass prodn. of reduced graphene oxide.

A facile hydrothermal strategy to synthesize sulfur-doped reduced graphene oxide (S-RGO) sheets with good cond. is proposed by using only graphene oxide (GO) sheets and sodium sulfide (Na2S) as precursors through a hydrothermal reaction process at 200 °C in one pot. The introduced Na2S can act as not only a sulfur dopant, but also as a highly efficient reducing agent in the formation of S-RGO sheets, which dramatically improves the elec. conductivities of the resulting S-RGO sheets compared with previous reports. The current reaches about 50.0 mA at an applied bias of 2.0 V for the optimized sample with 2.22 at% sulfur doping. This current value is much higher than that of RGO sheets (∼1.2 mA) annealed at 200 °C, and very close to that of single-layer graphene sheets (∼68.0 mA) prepd. using chem. vapor deposition under the same test conditions. The resulting highly conductive S-RGO sheets offer many promising technol. applications such as efficient metal-free electrocatalysts in oxygen redn. reactions in fuel cells and as supercapacitor electrode materials for high-performance Li-ion batteries.

Graphene oxide (GO) with various degrees of oxidn. was synthesized using a modified Hummers method. The formation of different types of oxygen contg. functional groups in GO, and their influences on its structure were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), FTIR spectra, X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), zeta potential anal. and Raman spectroscopy. XRD studies showed a disruption of the graphitic AB stacking order during the increase in oxidn. levels. XPS anal. revealed the formation of hydroxyl and carboxyl groups at lower oxidn. levels and epoxide groups at higher oxidn. levels. The influence of the oxidn. degree on the properties of GO was evaluated by zeta potential anal., which showed a linear increase in the zeta potential with increasing oxidn. levels. Raman spectroscopy anal. revealed that increasing oxidn. levels results in a transition from a cryst. to an amorphous structure. The electrochem. properties of GO is highly influenced by the variation in degree of oxidn. Our results suggest that the properties of GO can be tuned by varying the oxidn. degree, which may pave the way to new developments in the GO-based applications.

Although lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have 5-10 times higher theor. capacity (1675 mAh g-1) than present com. lithium-ion batteries, Li-S batteries show a rapid and continuous capacity fading due to the polysulfide dissoln. in common electrolytes. Here, we propose the use of a sulfur-based cathode material, amorphous MoS3 and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) composite, which can be substituted for the pure sulfur-based cathodes. In order to enhance kinetics and stability of the electrodes, we intentionally pulverize the microsized MoS3 sheet into nanosheets and form an ultrathin nano-SEI on the surface using in situ electrochem. methods. Then, the pulverized nanosheets are securely anchored by the oxygen functional group of r-GO. As a result, the electrochem. treated MoS3/r-GO electrode shows superior performance that surpasses pure sulfur-based electrodes; it exhibits a capacity of about 900 mAh g-1 at a rate of 5C for 2500 cycles without capacity fading. Moreover, a full-cell battery employing the MoS3/r-GO cathode with a silicon-carbon composite anode displays a 3-5 times higher energy d. (1725 Wh kg-1/7100 Wh L-1) than present LIBs.

We report here the field emission studies of a layered WS2-RGO composite at the base pressure of ~1 × 10(-8) mbar. The turn on field required to draw a field emission current density of 1 μA/cm(2) is found to be 3.5, 2.3 and 2 V/μm for WS2, RGO and the WS2-RGO composite respectively. The enhanced field emission behavior observed for the WS2-RGO nanocomposite is attributed to a high field enhancement factor of 2978, which is associated with the surface protrusions of the single-to-few layer thick sheets of the nanocomposite. The highest current density of ~800 μA/cm(2) is drawn at an applied field of 4.1 V/μm from a few layers of the WS2-RGO nanocomposite. Furthermore, first-principles density functional calculations suggest that the enhanced field emission may also be due to an overalp of the electronic structures of WS2 and RGO, where graphene-like states are dumped in the region of the WS2 fundamental gap.

Sen, Uttam Kumar; Johari, Priya; Basu, Sohini; Nayak, Chandrani; Mitra, Sagar

The lithium storage mechanism in molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has been comprehensively investigated as the existing conversion-based storage mechanism is unable to explain the reason behind its high practical capacity, high polarization losses, and the change in the discharge profile after the 1st charge-discharge cycle. To resolve these issues and to gain a deeper understanding of MoS2-based Li-ion batteries, for the first time, we have studied the reaction mechanism of the MoS2 anode using various exptl. techniques such as XRD, Raman spectroscopy, electrochem. impedance spectroscopy, XANES, and EXAFS, as well as ab initio d. functional theory based calcns. On the basis of the results presented here, and in line with some exptl. findings, we find that the reaction of MoS2 with Li is not as simple as with usual metal oxide based conversion reactions, but that the pathway of the conversion reaction changes after the first discharge process. In the first discharge process, lithiation is initiated by a limited intercalation process, followed by a conversion reaction that produces molybdenum nanoparticles (Mo) and lithium sulfide (Li2S). Whereas, unlike oxide-based conversion materials, MoS2 does not transverse back during the delithiation process. Indeed, instead of MoS2 formation, we identified the presence of polysulfur after the complete cycle. In consecutive cycles, polysulfur reacts with lithium and forms Li2S/Li2S2, and this Li-S reaction is found to be highly reversible in nature and the only source of the high practical capacity obsd. in this electrode. To validate our exptl. findings, an at. scale ab initio computational study was also carried out, which likewise suggests that Li first intercalates between the MoS2 layers but that after a certain concn., it reacts with MoS2 to form Li2S. The calcns. also support the non-reversibility of the conversion reaction, by showing that Mo + Li2S formation is energetically more favorable than the re-formation of MoS2 + Li.

As a typical transition metal dichalcogenide, MoS2 offers numerous advantages for nanoelectronics and electrochem. energy storage due to its unique layered structure and tunable electronic properties. When used as the anode in lithium-ion cells, MoS2 undergoes intercalation and conversion reactions in sequence upon lithiation, and the reversibility of the conversion reaction is an important but still controversial topic. Here, we clarify unambiguously that the conversion reaction of MoS2 is not reversible, and the formed Li2S is converted to sulfur in the first charge process. Li2S/sulfur becomes the main redox couple in the subsequent cycles and the main contributor to the reversible capacity. In addn., due to the insulating nature of both Li2S and sulfur, a strong relaxation effect is obsd. during the cycling process. This study clearly reveals the electrochem. lithiation-delithiation mechanism of MoS2, which can facilitate further developments of high-performance MoS2-based electrodes.

Few-layered graphene networks composed of phosphorus and nitrogen dual-doped porous graphene (PNG) are synthesized via a MgO-templated chem. vapor deposition (CVD) using (NH4)3PO4 as N and P source. P and N atoms have been substitutionally doped in graphene networks since the doping takes place at the same time with the graphene growth in the CVD process. Raman spectra show that the amt. of defects or disorders increases after P and N atoms are incorporated into graphene frameworks. The doping levels of P and N measured by XPS are 0.6 and 2.6 at %, resp. As anodes for Li ion batteries (LIBs), the PNG electrode exhibits high reversible capacity (2250 mAh/g at the c.d. of 50 mA/g), excellent rate capability (750 mAh/g at 1000 mA/g), and satisfactory cycling stability (no capacity decay after 1500 cycles), showing much enhanced electrode performance as compared to the undoped few-layered porous graphene. Our results show that the PNG is a promising candidate for anode materials in high-rate LIBs.

Two-dimensional nanosheets can leverage on their open architecture to support facile insertion and removal of Li+ as lithium-ion battery electrode materials. In this study, two two-dimensional nanosheets with complementary functions, namely nitrogen-doped graphene and few-layer WS2, were integrated via a facile surfactant-assisted synthesis under hydrothermal conditions. The layer structure and morphol. of the composites were confirmed by X-ray diffraction, SEM and high-resoln. transmission microscopy. The effects of surfactant amt. on the WS2 layer no. were investigated and the performance of the layered composites as high energy d. lithium-ion battery anodes was evaluated. The composite formed with a surfactant : tungsten precursor ratio of 1 : 1 delivered the best cyclability (av. of only 0.08% capacity fade per cycle for 100 cycles) and good rate performance (80% capacity retention with a 50-fold increase in c.d. from 100 mA g-1 to 5000 mA g-1), and may find uses in power-oriented applications.

It is well known that the nanocomponents with opposite charges can be easily assembled into hybrid composites via electrostatic interaction, but it is difficult for like-charged nanomaterials. Here, we developed a general method to directly assemble lamellar composite paper composed of both neg.-charged WS2 and graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets from their aq. dispersion through filtration process. After hydrothermal redn., the flexible lamellar WS2/reduced-graphene oxide (rGO) paper was evaluated as binder-free anodes for Li-ion batteries, which presented a reversible capacity of 697.7 mA h g-1 after 100 cycles, 8 times higher than 88.5 mA h g-1 of pure WS2 nanosheets and 60.2 mA h g-1 of rGO, excellent cyclic stability and good rate capacity. In the uniformly alternated lamellar structures, rGO nanosheets efficiently prevent the restacking of WS2 sheets, increase the cond. of the electrode, and sustain the vol. expansion during Li+ insertion/extn., which significantly improved the electrochem. performances. This simple filtration assembling method provides a general and efficient way to synthesize functional composite films from like-charged colloid solns.

Tungsten disulfide, which possesses a well-defined layered structure, has been intensively studied as an anode material for lithium ion batteries, but it usually suffers from poor cycling stability because of its large vol. changes during lithium insertion and extn. processes. Herein, we develop a self-assembled double carbon coating to enhance the anode performance of WS2 via a self-assembly process between oleylamine-coated WS2 nanosheets and graphene oxide and subsequent pyrolysis treatment. When employed as an anode material for lithium ion batteries, the as-prepd.
[email protected]
/reduced graphene oxide (
[email protected]
/RGO) composite exhibits excellent cycling stability and rate capability when compared to
[email protected]
nanosheets. A reversible capacity of 486 mA h g-1 and around 90% capacity retention were obtained after 200 cycles at a c.d. of 0.5 A g-1. Even under 10 A g-1, a high reversible capacity of 126 mA h g-1 can be retained. The good electrochem. performance could be attributed to the external electronically conductive and flexible RGO coating in addn. to the surface carbon layer and the uniform distribution of WS2 nanosheets. The self-assembled dual carbon coating strategy is facile yet effective, and it may be applied to other high-capacity anode materials with huge vol. changes and poor elec. conductivities.

WS2 nanosheets-carbon composites (WS2/C) were synthesized through a simple two-step process including ball-milling and sulfidation. When applied as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries and lithium-ion batteries, WS2/C composites deliver a high reversible sodium storage capacity of 270 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and a high reversible lithium storage capacity of 322 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1 after 100 cycles. The improved electrochem. performance of WS2/C compared with the bare WS2 can be attributed to the synergic effects between WS2 and Super P carbon black matrix, which can offer a beneficial cond. environment for electron transfer and accommodate stress from the vol. change during cycling.

Two-dimensional transition-metal dichalcogenides, such as tungsten disulfide (WS2), have been actively studied as suitable candidates for anode materials used in lithium ion batteries recently, due to their remarkable ion intercalation properties. However, the difficulties in the synthesis of phase-pure WS2, restacking between WS2 nanosheets, low electronic cond. and brittle nature of WS2 severely limit its Li-ion batteries application. Here, we adopt a one-pot method for synthesizing of WS2/reduced Graphene Oxide (rGO) composite to improve the battery performance dramatically. The WS2/rGO anode shows a stable discharge capacity of 431.2 mA h/g, at a c.d. of 0.1 A/g after 100 cycles, while the capacity of bare WS2 is only 65.5 mA h/g under the same condition. The added graphene oxide is reduced to rGO in reaction process and constitute stable composite with WS2, not only avoiding the restacking between WS2 nanosheets and improving the conductive properties, but also promoting the redn. of WO3 effectively. Our work may provide a possible route to avoid oxygen impurities in transition metal dichalcogenides.

This review covers key technol. developments and scientific challenges for a broad range of Li-ion battery electrodes. Periodic table and potential/capacity plots are used to compare many families of suitable materials. Performance characteristics, current limitations, and recent breakthroughs in the development of com. intercalation materials such as lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM), lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), lithium titanium oxide (LTO) and others are contrasted with that of conversion materials, such as alloying anodes (Si, Ge, Sn, etc.), chalcogenides (S, Se, Te), and metal halides (F, Cl, Br, I). New polyanion cathode materials are also discussed. The cost, abundance, safety, Li and electron transport, volumetric expansion, material dissoln., and surface reactions for each type of electrode materials are described. Both general and specific strategies to overcome the current challenges are covered and categorized.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

Si has been regarded as one of the most promising next generation lithium-ion battery (LIB) anodes due to its exceptional capacity and proper working voltage. However, the dramatic vol. change during lithiation/delithiation processes has caused severe detrimental consequences, leading to very poor cyclic stability. It has been one of the crit. problems hampering the practical applications of the silicon based LIB anode. Extensive research has been carried out to resolve the problem since early 1990s. For the first time, the studies on the Si anode in the time frame more than two decades are summarized and discussed in this review with a novel chronicle perspective. Through this article, the evolution of the concept, fundamental scientific and technol. development of the silicon LIB anode are clearly presented. It provides unique eyesight into this rapid developing field and will shed light on the future trend of the Si LIB anode research.

A review. Tungsten is the heaviest transition metal in the family of common transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs). Despite the essential similarities of TMDCs, the considerable differences in the size and charge of the building elements can make the typical 2D layered structure suitable for various applications. There is not much flexibility on the chalcogen side, as the popular elements are S and Se. Following the successful history of transition metal sulfides in various applications, transition metal selenides are now the rising stars. On the transition metal side, WS2 and WSe2 have recently attracted considerable attention. In comparison with the Mo counterparts, W is more abundant in the Earth's crust and thus cheaper, and less toxic. The significantly larger size of W atoms can substantially tune the TMDC properties. The popularity of molybdenum dichalcogenides has somehow overshadowed the potentials of tungsten dichalcogenides. This manuscript attempts to collect the recent reports on various applications of WS2 and WSe2 to provide a general overview of tungsten dichalcogenides. Due to the popularity of sulfides, the prime focus of the present review is on WSe2, which is an emerging member of this family. Although WTe2 is not a common material like all transition metal tellurides, it is also briefly reviewed as a member of this sub-family of TMDCs owing to its unique properties, which named it as a potential candidate for giant magnetoresistance and supercond.

A review. Advanced electrodes with a high energy d. at high power are urgently needed for high-performance energy storage devices, including lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and supercapacitors (SCs), to fulfill the requirements of future electrochem. power sources for applications such as in hybrid elec./plug-in-hybrid (HEV/PHEV) vehicles. Metal sulfides with unique phys. and chem. properties, as well as high specific capacity/capacitance, which are typically multiple times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials, are currently studied as promising electrode materials. However, the implementation of these sulfide electrodes in practical applications is hindered by their inferior rate performance and cycling stability. Nanostructures offering the advantages of high surface-to-vol. ratios, favorable transport properties, and high freedom for the vol. change upon ion insertion/extn. and other reactions, present an opportunity to build next-generation LIBs and SCs. Thus, the development of novel concepts in material research to achieve new nanostructures paves the way for improved electrochem. performance. Herein, we summarize recent advances in nanostructured metal sulfides, such as iron sulfides, copper sulfides, cobalt sulfides, nickel sulfides, manganese sulfides, molybdenum sulfides, tin sulfides, with zero-, one-, two-, and three-dimensional morphologies for LIB and SC applications. In addn., the recently emerged concept of incorporating conductive matrixes, esp. graphene, with metal sulfide nanomaterials will also be highlighted. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and perspectives for the future development of metal sulfide-based LIB and SC devices.

Thin films of tungsten sulfide (WS2) are prepd. by at. layer deposition (ALD) and its intercalation properties as an anode material in Li-ion battery are studied. The self-satn. growth of the material and the temp. window for ALD growth is confirmed by in situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM). In situ Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR) and residual gas analyzer (RGA) studies help to predict the two half reactions and FTIR further validates the self-limiting feature of ALD growth. The as-grown WS2 is amorphous in nature and characterized in detail by XPS and Raman spectroscopic anal. The as-grown films are tested as a suitable intercalation based material for Li-ion battery anode. CV measurements are carried out extensively to explore the dominant intercalation property of the WS2 anode. Stable cycling performance with high coulombic efficiency (>99%) up to 100 charge-discharge cycles is obsd. To enhance the performance further, multi walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) scaffold layer is introduced that helps to deposit more active material for the same no. of ALD cycles.

Although tungsten disulfide (WS2), an analog of graphite, has long been pursued as a promising energy storage material due to its unique layered structure, structural changes, volumetric expansion and poor electronic cond. have limited its practical use. Here, we report the synthesis of porous WS2 composed of a few layered nanosheets (P-WS2) using a simple and scalable hydrothermal method, as well as its electrochem. properties when used for a lithium storage electrode, a supercapacitor electrode, and a visible light active photocatalytic material. P-WS2 as an anode for lithium-ion batteries showed a high specific capacity of 292 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 0.2C with excellent cycling stability over 100 cycles. The half-cell electrochem. assembly test demonstrated that P-WS2 delivered 241.5 F/g at a c.d. of 0.75 A/g and showed excellent stability over 2000 consecutive charge-discharge cycles. P-WS2 nanosheets exhibited 10 times higher photocatalytic activity than bulk com. WS2 (C-WS2) for the degrdn. of Rhodamine B dye under visible light irradn. The excellent performance of P-WS2 is due to its sheet-like structure, porous characteristics, and high surface area.

Nanostructured materials offer the possibility to make use of small transport lengths and small sepn. distances similar to fluids, but unlike fluids, the higher structural stability of the solid state can be taken advantage of. Recent results on Li-batteries highlight the potential for room temp. applications. Advantages and disadvantages of nanostructured matter are discussed with respect to stability, storage capacity, voltage and charging/discharging rates. A novel interfacial storage mechanism for Li which, in the mesoscopic case, forms a bridge between batteries and capacitors, is presented.

A review. This is the first targeted review of the synthesis - microstructure - electrochem. performance relations of MoS2 - based anodes and cathodes for secondary lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Molybdenum disulfide is a highly promising material for LIBs that compensates for its intermediate insertion voltage (∼2 V vs. Li/Li+) with a high reversible capacity (up to 1290 mA h g-1) and an excellent rate capability (e.g. 554 mA h g-1 after 20 cycles at 50 C). Several themes emerge when surveying the scientific literature on the subject: first, we argue that there is excellent data to show that truly nanoscale structures, which often contain a nanodispersed carbon phase, consistently possess superior charge storage capacity and cycling performance. We provide several hypotheses regarding why the measured capacities in such architectures are well above the theor. predictions of the known MoS2 intercalation and conversion reactions. Second, we highlight the growing microstructural and electrochem. evidence that the layered MoS2 structure does not survive past the initial lithiation cycle, and that subsequently the electrochem. active material is actually elemental sulfur. Third, we show that certain synthesis techniques are consistently demonstrated to be the most promising for battery applications, and describe these in detail. Fourth, we present our selection of synthesis methods that we believe to have a high potential for creating improved MoS2 LIB electrodes, but are yet to be tried.
